body: TWO months ago the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, overseers of the sprawling industrial park on the East River, inaugurated its own steam production system, enabling it to provide steam to its tenants at rates below those of Consolidated Edison. On its agenda for 1983 are further development of plans for a permanent co-generation plant
title: Real Estate; Brooklyn Navy Yard Program

body: "At any political meeting, nine-tenths of the questions from the homeowners are about multifamily housing,'' says Hy Sardy, chairman of the Midwood Development Corporation in Brooklyn. When homeowners live in areas that have high concentrations of rental housing, preservation of the quality of the rental stock becomes a major concern. Accordingly,
title: HOMEOWNERS WORKING TO IMPROVE RENTAL PROPERTY

body: A Thousand Warm Hands N ot least among the city's giftgivers yesterday was Michael Greenberg, an advertising account executive at Ted Bates, who each Christmas Eve for the last 18 years has distributed gloves to the homeless on the Bowery. Taking up a collection of single gloves at his office, he gathered over 300 this time and was able to put
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: The six cable-television companies that were awarded rights to wire the boroughs outside of Manhattan under an agreement concluded yesterday are variously owned by large communications concerns and small local ventures. Manhattan has been served for more than a decade by Manhattan Cable TV in the southern portion and Teleprompter in the northern
title: LARGE AND SMALL COMPANIES AMONG THE WINNERS OF CABLE CONTRACTS

body: When the Oceanfront Development Corporation, a local community organization in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, sought help to upgrade the Neptune Avenue commercial district last year, it contacted the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the voluntary charitable agency. The federation responded by helping the community group
title: CHARITABLE GROUP FIGHTS CITY DECAY

body: Two years of progress in planning for New York City's solid waste disposal has stopped dead because Comptroller Harrison Goldin noticed that the Board of Estimate was discussing a recovery plant in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard. People live near the yard, and they understandably do not want a garbage plant nearby. No one does. Yet the city has only
title: Wasting Precious Time on Waste

body: A 16-year-old student who refused to give up his gold chain was shot and seriously wounded yesterday by two other students outside the cafeteria of Eastern District High School in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said. One of the fleeing suspects, also 16, was arrested by a police officer patrolling outside the school after the youth
title: BROOKLYN YOUTH SHOT BY ROBBERS AT A HIGH SCHOOL

body: HIGHWAYS crumble and bridges shake, sewer systems are overtaxed, reservoirs underfilled and dams overflowing. Is it any wonder, after years of not-so-benign neglect, that officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut decry the state of their states? But if infrastructure has become a watchword, finding the funds for the increasingly huge public
title: SHAKY BRIDGES IN NEW YORK

body: WHEN fire destroyed a four-story, 16-unit apartment building at 2303C larendon Road in Brooklyn recently, all but six tenants in the a djoining structure, at 2307, had to move out of their apartments. ' 'They were identical buildings served by the same boiler,'' said B rent Sharman, the tenant organizer for the Flatbush Development C orporation, a
title: WEATHERIZING HOMES OF THE POOR

body: While it does not pose a threat to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in New York City, the New Rochelle Thanksgiving Parade, now in its 21st year, is the only one in Westchester, and it draws thousands of spectators from all parts of the county. Beginning at 10 A.M. Saturday, rain or shine, the parade will step off from New Rochelle High School,
title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE; NEW ROCHELLE PARADE

body: A sure sign of a Jewish neighborhood is a synagogue or a kosher butcher shop. But in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, everything seems kosher - the hardware store, the barber shop, the schools, the architecture, the clothing store, even the buses. What's more, there is a synagogue on almost every block. ''Every facet of Hasidic life is governed by
title: A TOUR OF HASIDIC WILLIAMSBURG

body: Almost 4,000 jobs have been created or saved in New York City by an 18-month-old Consolidated Edison Company program that offers reduced electricity rates to commercial customers who agree to expand or relocate in depressed neighborhoods, according to the city and the utility. More than 1,000 businesses in the South Bronx and parts of Brooklyn have
title: CON ED RATES PROGRAM CLAIMS PROGRESS ON JOBS

body: ART What should a new museum in Brooklyn mount but - a show about Brooklyn! The new center, in Boylan Hall on Brooklyn College's Flatbush campus, is called the Museum of the Borough of Brooklyn, and its concern is Brooklyn's rich ''visual and cultural history.'' Its first exhibition - in celebration of the centennials of Franklin D. Roosevelt and
title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES

body: The New York Court of Appeals, faced with escalating caseloads, cumbersome procedures and the mandatory retirement of five of its seven members in a little more than three years, is entering what leading lawyers and the judges themselves believe could be both the most troublesome and the most promising period in its history. For generations the
title: NEW YORK'S COURT OF APPEALS FACES VAST CHANGES AS A NEW ERA BEGINS

body: Six years late and nearly four times its original projected cost, Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center opened yesterday as a municipal hospital in northern Brooklyn and admitted its first patients. With a daily Medicaid rate of $557 a day, the huge, ultramodern hospital is $4 a day more expensive than Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in
title: NEW HOSPITAL OPENS DOORS, 6 YEARS LATE

body: The very first article, some 69 years ago, contained a bit of the foolishness of a bright but badly informed 11-year-old. Dear editor, it said to The New York Tribune in 1913, I'm shocked to learn that the entire 3,000-mile border with Canada is unfortified. That not very impressive beginning by Sidney Hook was followed by deeper, better-informed
title: 300 HONOR SIDNEY HOOK AS DEFENDER OF REASON

body: Mayor Koch, faced with opposition on the Board of Estimate to his plan to build a large incinerator in the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, withdrew two proposed contracts yesterday and accused Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin of sabotaging the plan for ''political benefits.'' Mr. Koch's actions came after he failed in nearly two days of attempts to persuade
title: KOCH YIELDS IN MOVE FOR NAVY YARD PLANT

body: Remembering John Wayne In Williamsburg W ay out west in Williamsburg, Public School 380 was dedicated yesterday as the John Wayne Elementary School. It was a great day for the Cowboys, as the school's sports program is now called. It was also a great day, however exotic, for the Wayne family. In a rare reunion, six of the late actor's seven
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: WHAT is the perfect way to watch the New York Marathon? To run in it, surely - a privilege that will be denied all but 16,000 of the more than two million people who will turn out on Sunday to be part of it. The lucky entrants will see some authentic New York curiosities: Fort Wadsworth at dawn, for one, the Staten Island gathering point for
title: TIPS FOR MARATHON FANS

body: Edolphus Towns, the deputy borough president of Brooklyn, won the Democratic nomination for the 11th Congressional District. He defeated two others in the race to fill the seat vacated by Representative Frederick W. Richmond. Mr. Towns is almost assured of election in November in the district, which is overwhelmingly Democratic and which was
title: TOWNS WIN IN BID FOR RICHMOND'S SEAT

body: While battle lines were late in forming in the 11th Congressional District after former Representative Frederick W. Richmond was forced to withdraw his bid for re-election, Edolphus Towns succeeded in gaining the Democratic organization's support for the primary tomorrow. In addition, Mr. Towns also received the support of insurgents. For example,
title: DEMOCRATS SEEK RICHMOND'S SEAT IN A 3-WAY RACE

body: New Brooklyn School To Be Named for Wayne A s best as can be reckoned, John Wayne never walked the streets of Williamsburg. But he is not without devotees out there in Brooklyn. On Marcy Street, the new Public School 380 is about to be formally named the John Wayne Elementary School. It is believed to be the first school in the country named after
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: THE classically inspired building at 825 West Hartsdale Road in the town of Greenburgh has remained largely unchanged since it was erected in 1908, its interior divided into living quarters on the east end and a large studio extending from the ground floor to the skylighted roof at the west end. But in celebration of the creative genius that was
title: HOUSE NAMED FOR ROLE IN SHAPING WORLD OF SCULPTURE

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: A Better Mark for Streets L ast month, 64 percent of New York's 6,000 miles of streets were ''acceptably clean,'' according to Project Scorecard. A year ago August, only 57 percent made the grade. Project Scorecard is the city's way of measuring street litter. Every month 12 trained inspectors from the Mayor's office examine 6,640 blocks and give
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: More than 350 courses in women's studies at 53 educational institutions and women's centers throughout the city are included in a new publication from the New York City Commission on the Status of Women. Entitled ''Guide to Women's Studies,'' the 72-page booklet offers a wide-ranging selection. The courses are on such topics as: starting a
title: COURSES FOR WOMEN IN THE CITY

body: The accidental severing of a power line in a Brooklyn office of the New York Telephone Company yesterday led to a power failure that cut off operator-assisted telephone service throughout Queens and in parts of Manhattan and Staten Island. The failure occured at 3:30 A.M., and by evening, John Quinn, a spokesman for the company, said repairs would
title: MISHAP CURTAILS TELEPHONE CALLS FOR 3 BUROUGHS

body: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was fatally shot in his bedroom Friday while he and a friend were handling a .44-caliber gun, the police said yesterday. The youth, Ray Charles, of 125 Sanford Street in the Williamsburg section, was shot in the head with a gun the friend had brought to the home, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Thomas Fahey. The youth was
title: Boy, 13, Slain; Friend Seized

body: Rabbi Eliezer Zisya Portugal, who came to the United States in 1960 after helping hundreds of Jews emigrate from the Soviet Union and his native Rumania to Israel, died yesterday at the age of 86. Last night, thousands of Hasidic Jews crowded the streets around the tiny Chesed l'Abraham Synagogue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn to pay
title: ELIEZER PORTUGAL, RABBI, DEAD AT 86

body: When Allen Kaplan was in college, he thought practicing law might be a nice way to make a living. However, like many other young men, Allen knew his family had other plans for him, and deep down inside, he was yellow. Cabs were in his blood. One whiff of gasoline and he could see the family fleet garage in his mind's eye, see his grandfather the
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic

Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic$12o: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B. Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive: Two lanes will be closed in either direction from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery. Also, the southbound ramp at Robert F. Wagner Sr. Place will be closed. C. Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges: Outer roadways on both bridges will be closed because of rehabilitation projects. D. Belt Parkway: In Brooklyn, traffic in all three northbound lanes will be detoured because of continuing road work on the Owls Head Viaduct. E. Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway: Substantial delays anticipated between Nyack (Exit 11) and Spring Valley (Exit 14), where lanes will be closed because of road work at four overpass locations: Route 59, Hackensack River, Strawtown Road and North Middletown Road. F. Garden State Parkway: One lane will be closed in each direction for bridge repairs at Schoolhouse Road and Williams Road. G. I-495: One lane will be closed at Routes 1 and 9 on the westbound overpass for viaduct repairs. H. New Jersey Turnpike: One lane will be closed at westbound Interchange 14C for bridge deck replacement. I. I-84: Major delays are expected for westbound traffic at the Route 121 overpass, about one mile east of I-684. J. East 241st Street Bridge: This bridge, which connects the Bronx and Yonkers, will be closed for a major rehabilitation project. Note: Motorists may also experience delays at facilities operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, several of which recently increased their tolls to $1.25. Exact change or bridge tokens are recommended at toll plazas at the Triborough, Verrazano-Narrows, Bronx Whitestone and Throgs Neck Bridges and at the Queens Midtown and Brooklyn Battery Tunnels. Source: Automobile Club of New York The New York Times/Aug. 6, 1982

body: Crimes against teachers and other staff members in New York City's public schools have declined significantly for the first time in the decade that the United Federation of Teachers has kept such statistics. Figures provided yesterday by the teachers' union for the school year that ended in June show a drop of 22 percent in assaults, robberies,
title: STUDENTS' CRIMES AGAINST TEACHERS ARE DOWN BY 22%

body: A Postal Lesson In Subtraction I t's not vandalism but economy that is claiming hundreds of mailboxes around town. Brooklyn has lost 386, or 17 percent, since March, leaving it with 1,946. Manhattan has lost 250, nearly 10 percent, since June. Queens and Staten Island, losing more than 2 percent, still have 4,000 and 504 boxes respectively, while
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

title: REGION IN SUMMARY; Ma Bell Still; Has Dependents

title: THE CITY; Lane to Manhattan On Bridge Is Shut

body: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that New York City may continue with its plan to replace the 67-year-old Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn with the modern Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center. The decision, issued by Justice William T. Bellard in Brooklyn, modified his injunction of May 21 against the plan developed by the city's Health
title: COURT UPHOLDS CLOSING OF GREENPOINT HOSPITAL

body: International A fierce artillery fight in west Beirut seemed to indicate that the Palestinian guerrillas besieged by Israeli armored units still had a great deal of ammunition, weapons and resolve. For the first time, the Palestinians fired back on Israeli gun positions in Christian east Beirut. The battle broke up negotiations for a settlement as
title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 12, 1982

body: The number of reported robberies in a high-crime Brooklyn precinct has dropped 44 percent in the six months since the police began a program they say stresses old-fashioned police work. ''We reinvented the wheel,'' said Deputy Inspector John J. Hill, the commander of the precinct, the 90th, in the Williamsburg section. The program was begun last
title: ROBBERY REPORTS DECLINE BY 44% IN ONE PRECINCT

body: The Justice Department today rejected the New York State Legislature's plans to reapportion Congressional, State Senate and Assembly districts on the ground that they discriminated against minority groups in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan. The action caught New York State politicians by surprise, and Governor Carey immediately signed a bill
title: NEW YORK STATE'S PLANS TO REVISE VOTE DISTRICTS REJECTED AS BIASED

body: NEW CASTLE A remote corner of this community is decidedly suburban, but the language there is Yiddish. An 8-year-old boy politely but incredulously asks a visitor, ''You don't speak Yiddish?'' Then a younger boy on a banana-seat bicycle tears down the hill that is Tora Road, his peyos, or hair locks, flying in the wind. At the top of the hill is
title: HASIDIM FLOURISH IN SUBURBAN SETTING

body: The Conservative Party gave Lewis E. Lehrman its nomination for Governor today, insuring that he will be on the November ballot no matter what happens in the Republican primary. An effort to let his Republican rival, Paul J. Curran, compete in a Conservative primary was rejected by party leaders. In a one-day meeting at the Turf Inn in this Albany
title: NEW YORK'S MINOR PARTIES SELECT STATEWIDE CANDIDATES

body: The police said they were searching yesterday for a suspect in several robberies and a homicide who fired two shots at officers trying to capture him in Brooklyn Saturday night. One officer was slightly injured by flying glass from a bullet-pierced patrol car windshield. The suspect, identified by the police as 22-year-old Felix Lagoy, was seen by
title: THE CITY

body: A man suspected of robbery and homicide fired at least two shots at a police car in Brooklyn last night, the police said. An officer inside was cut on the hand by flying glass when a window shattered. The injured officer, Dennis Doyle, of the 90th Precinct, was treated at Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn and released, according to Sgt. Tom Fahey, a
title: A Shot Hits Police Car; Officer Is Hurt by Glass

body: In a six-year-old program in Brooklyn that combines the traditional curriculum of a yeshiva with the latest techniques of special education, 100 boys with learning disabilities study English and Hebrew in an environment designed to help them and their families cope with their special needs. ''The learning-disabled child has to learn how to learn,
title: JEWISH CENTER AIDS LEARNING DISABLED

body: As New Yorkers take to the roads for their first long weekend of the season, they are likely to encounter fewer traffic bottlenecks than on Memorial Days past. ''Construction delays for those headed for the shore should pose less of a problem this year,'' said John A. Marino Jr., head of the New York City office of the state's Transportation
title: TRAFFIC OUTLOOK: SMOOTH SUMMER, BUT TROUBLE DOWN THE ROAD

body: Woodhull Hospital, a multimillion-dollar structure that has stood unused in Brooklyn for four years, is to accept its first patients today. Woodhull's family-care center will be the first section of the hospital to go into operation, according to Thomas Ricke, a spokesman for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. He said the other sections
title: THE CITY; Woodhull Hospital Taking Patients

body: Over the last five years, the Borough Park section of Brooklyn has become one of the most ambitious centers of residential real estate activity in the city. According to specialists in property sales and mortgage loans, land prices have soared as contractors buy old frame houses on side streets off the main avenues, demolish them and build new
title: HOUSING SURGE ALTERS BOROUGH PARK

body: Putting the period to a period film is a demanding business, an expensive one, too, that becomes even more challenging if the period is one that lies within the memory of living man. ''The Chosen,'' at the Beekman and Cinema 3, is a case in point, a movie that recalls a Brooklyn of the late 1940's and does so with such fidelity that the tree-lined
title: BRINGING BROOKLYN OF THE 1940'S BACK TO LIFE FOR 'THE CHOSEN'

body: A man suspected of shooting at a couple in Queens at 9 A.M. yesterday was chased into a Brooklyn candy store about noon by two officers. The suspect, 49-year-old John Doherty of 485 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, barricaded himself in the bathroom of the store, at 118 Kane Street, and fired a single shot. The officers fired back three times before the man
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: If there were an award for the Congressman who flouts the law most and seems the least perturbed by it, it would certainly have to go this year to Representative Frederick Richmond of Brooklyn. And if there were a companion award for condoning this behavior, it would belong to the House of Representatives ethics committee. Investigations do not a
title: NEW YORK; A JOLLY GOOD FELLOW

body: Charles W. Froessel, a former associate judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He lived in Forest Hills, Queens, and was 89 years old. He was elected to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, in 1949. In his final year on the bench, he voted with the majority in the court's
title: CHARLES FROESSEL, EX-JUDGE, IS DEAD

body: The 360-foot-high Health Sciences Center on the campus of the State University of New York at Stony Brook is generally acknowledged to be the tallest building on Long Island. But nothing is ever that simple. Over at Mitchel Field there is a hole in the ground that will soon be covered by the two 15-story towers of European American Bank Plaza. The
title: POSTINGS; THE TALLEST ON LONG ISLAND

body: Thomas G. Rizzo lived surrounded by stark, stunning portraits of other people's ancestors, a half-dozen folk-art landscapes and several remarkable weathervanes. Until his sudden death at 53 years of age last November, his home, high above Manhattan's East River, was a repository for his folk-art collection which he acquired over more than 30 years,
title: ANTIQUE'S VIEW; AN EYE FOR THE FINEST OF FOLK ART

body: Fort Greene House Tour, departing from Williamsburg Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, 643-1603. title: ANTIQUES, ORCHIDS AND HOUSE TOURS

title: TRAFFIC SNARLS EASE AT TOLL CROSSINGS; CITY OFFICIALS ASSESS MONDAY'S ; CHAOS

Richmond, the subject of a Federal investigation, to ''resign immediately for the good of the Democratic Party.'' title: RICHMOND IS ASKED BY ESPOSITO TO QUIT FOR THE PARTY'S SAKE

body: A supermarket in the South Bronx paid a $4,365 electricity bill last month. It might have paid $5,573, had it not been for a rate reduction of almost 22 percent from Consolidated Edison. A small doll factory in Brooklyn paid $174 instead of the $218 it would normally have been billed, and a Bronx plastics manufacturer whose February electricity
title: CON ED'S DISCOUNTS HELP GENERATE NEW JOBS

body: Two municipal hospitals in the Bronx are to be merged under a single administration in an effort to reduce costs and provide more efficient medical care, according to the president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. The merger - of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center and North Central Bronx Hospital - will be the first for the city's
title: CITY WILL MERGE 2 HOSPITALS IN THE BRONX TO SAVE MONEY

body: First came Herman I. Kraus, then Kraus Management, Kraus Enterprises, Kraus Security System, Kraus Maintenance and, when they all needed legal help, Kraus & Kraus. The result of layer after layer of Kraus companies is that the 650 tenants of a Broklyn housing project that Mr. Kraus owns and operates and the city and Federal governments, which
title: HOUSING PROJECT OWNER'S PRACTICES CRITISIZED

body: A senior at the High School of Music and Art who was beaten on the head by a gang with baseball bats on a subway platform in Harlem two weeks ago died Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital after extensive brain surgery. The victim, 17-year old Steven Crosland, never regained consciousness after the assault. He had been attending a talent show at the
title: HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR DIES AFTER CLUBBING BY GANG

body: The rain slanted down on the harbor as the tugboat Brian McAllister pulled alongside the 600-foot Don Salvador III, a Filipino cargo ship docked at a Brooklyn pier. It took 40 minutes, as the tug pushed and pulled, to guide the unwieldy ship safely on its way. As the freighter began to pull away from the pier, the tugboat crew noticed a tanker
title: IN NEW YORK HARBOR, SAFETY IS A COMPLEX TASK

body: A construction worker who was suspended from the underside of the Williamsburg Bridge on the day a gasoline tanker exploded below in the East River testified yesterday that he had seen ''nothing unusual'' happening on the vessel as she passed under the bridge. The worker, Charles Jensen of Brooklyn, was the final witness on the fifth day of
title: WORKER RECALLS TANKER PASSING BEFORE THE BLAST

body: The gasoline tanker that blew up in the East River on Feb. 26 exploded before it reached the Williamsburg Bridge, according to testimony by eyewitnesses yesterday at a hearing into the causes of the blast. ''Everything happened north of the bridge,'' Louis Pantano, an employee at the Amstar Corporation's sugar refinery in Brooklyn, told a Coast
title: WITNESSES DIFFER ON WHERE TANKER EXPLODED

body: A three-alarm fire on Wednesday severely damaged the new main building of Boricua College in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The building, at Bedford Avenue and North Sixth Street, was not occupied. The four-year college, which is nine years old and has 900 students, had been in the process of moving from its location at 9 Graham Avenue to
title: A Fire Damages Main Building Of Boricua College in Brooklyn

body: A three-alarm fire destroyed the interior of the former St. Francis Prep High School in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday, according to a Fire Department spokesman. The blaze broke out in the three-story brick building at 186 North Sixth Street at 11:24 A.M., the spokesman said. Another fire was reported at 12:23 P.M. in a Sanitation
title: Fires Damage Former School And Two Piers on the Hudson

body: A suspicious two-alarm blaze destroyed a Hasidic school and synagogue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday, a spokesman for the Fire Deparment reported. And last night in the Bronx, two firefighters were injured as a blaze roared through a six-story apartment building in the Bedford Park section, according to the spokesman, John
title: 2 FIREMEN INJURED AND SCHOOL DESTROYED IN SEPARATE BLAZES

body: A gasoline tanker exploded, burst into flames and sank in the East River yesterday morning, killing one crew member and injuring three others, moments after it passed under the Williamsburg Bridge. A huge chunk of steel was flung 135 feet into the air and landed on the subway tracks of the bridge, halting one train and closing the bridge to cars
title: SEAMAN IS KILLED AS TANKER SINKS INTO EAST RIVER

body: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he opposed the extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 as approved in a bill in the House of Representatives last fall and that he favored instead an extension of the present act. The bill, which includes an amendment to the present act that would prohibit any law ''which results in a denial or
title: D'AMATO OPPOSES AMENDMENT TO RIGHTS ACT

body: Encouraged perhaps by compassionate teachers, youngsters are learning the meaning of sharing and giving, and many are contributing through their classrooms to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Betty T. Moon, a teacher in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, sent a donation of $8.70 contributed by her second-graders in Public School 380 to
title: STUDENTS LEARN HOW TO SHARE BY GIVING TO NEEDIEST CASES

body: International The U.S. and China are involved in ''extremely sensitive discussions'' over the Taiwan issue, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said. but he was ''not in a position to predict the outcome.'' American officials had previously said that talks were going on with Peking over its complaints about the Administration's decision to
title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1982

body: From his executive suite in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Vic Barouh can check the sales reports from his $150 million officeequipment empire, call his factories in Ireland and Puerto Rico, watch his Ko-Rec-Type trucks fill on the loading docks and recall the day he started his business in 1955 with $48,000. What he finds himself thinking
title: AN ANGRY BUSINESSMAN'S WAR ON CRIME

body: Three men held u p the Wahba Trading Company on the fifth floor of 163 West 23d Street early yesterday and escap ed with $4,900 in cash. The owner, Ibram Wahba, 50 years old, was sho t and stabbed when he walked in on the robbery. The gunmen had forc ed eight employees into a back room and were beating Mr. Wahba's hand cuffed brother, Isaac, 57,
title: THE CITY; THE POLICE BLOTTER

body: Jack Gilford is a comedian turned actor, which is neither to put him down nor to elevate him to some starchy pantheon. It is merely to put forth the paradox of a man who, as stand-up, never did the oneliners that were comic staple, but, in theater, delivered a one-liner so powerful that it proved to be a show-stopper. And now, nearly 30 years
title: JACK GILFORD REVISITS 'ALEICHEM'

body: Despite mon ths of dispute about the way the Koch administration grants tax ab atements and exemptions to real estate developers, the City Council finally passed a bill this week that keeps things very much the way they were. The often heated debate has brought a heightened political sensitivity. And that may make it more difficult for developers
title: ABATEMENTS PERSIST; News Analysis

body: A pattern of discrepancies in the reporting of campaign contributions made to Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn has emerged in an examination of official records and in interviews with listed givers and aides. Some of the discrepancies concern thousands of dollars raised by a Brooklyn shipyard operator who got hundreds of millions of
title: LAWMAKER'S FUNDS CLOUDED BY FLAWS
